title: 107_hr3917
content: The Act may be cited as the "Flight 93 National Memorial Act" and includes findings and purposes. The Flight 93 National Memorial Act acknowledges the heroic actions of passengers and crew on United Airlines Flight 93 on September 11, 2001, who thwarted an attack on the Nation's Capital. The site has drawn thousands of visitors, and concerns about its future disposition are being addressed by the Flight 93 Task Force. The crash site of Flight 93 is a symbol of American patriotism and leadership. Recognition at the site is a ongoing process to address concerns of all parties. It is proposed to designate the site as a unit of the National Park System to honor the passengers and crew of the flight. The bill aims to authorize the Secretary of the Interior to coordinate and facilitate activities for a permanent memorial for the passengers and crew of Flight 93. A memorial is established at the crash site of United Airlines Flight 93 in Pennsylvania to honor the passengers and crew. Additionally, a Flight 93 Advisory Commission is created. The Flight 93 Advisory Commission is established with 15 members, including the Director of the National Park Service. The members appoint a Chair and meet quarterly. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Flight 93 Advisory Commission, consisting of 15 members including the Director of the National Park Service, meets quarterly. Commission meetings are public and subject to open meeting laws. A majority of members forms a quorum. Members serve without compensation but can be reimbursed for expenses. The Commission's duties include submitting a report with recommendations for a permanent memorial at the crash site within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The Flight 93 Advisory Commission advises the Secretary on the boundaries and management plan of the memorial site. They consult with relevant parties and involve the public in the planning and design process. The Commission has the power to make necessary expenditures for carrying out their duties. The Flight 93 Advisory Commission has the authority to solicit donations, hold hearings, enter contracts, and delegate duties to National Park Service employees. The Commission will terminate upon the dedication of the completed memorial. SEC. 5. DUTIES OF THE SECRETARY. The Secretary is authorized to provide assistance to the Commission for various activities including collections, oral history interviews, public meetings, project management, memorial exhibits, staff support, and construction of the memorial. The Secretary is authorized to assist the Commission in various activities for the Flight 93 memorial, including acquiring land, constructing the memorial, and administering it as part of the National Park System. SEC. 6. CLARIFICATION OF PASSENGERS AND CREW. The terrorists on United Airlines Flight 93 on September 11, 2001, shall not be considered passengers or crew of that flight.
